Line 11: Line 11:

}}
â
'''MokaFive''', (previously '''''Moka5''''') headquartered in [[Redwood City, California]], provides [[virtualization]] software for managing desktop computers. moka5 was founded in July 2005 as a spinoff of the Collective Project in [[Stanford University]]'s Computer Science Department. moka5's main product, moka5 LivePC Engine, allows users to create, run, and share [[LivePC]]s, which are complete managed virtual computing environments that can be streamed or demand-paged over the network. These LivePCs can be shared with others on the moka5 web site or put on a portable drive for use on different computers.
+
'''MokaFive''', (previously '''''Moka5''''') headquartered in [[Redwood City, California]], provides [[virtualization]] software for managing desktop computers. MokaFive was founded in July 2005 as a spinoff of the Collective Project in [[Stanford University]]'s Computer Science Department. MokaFive's main product, MokaFive LivePC Engine, allows users to create, run, and share [[LivePC]]s, which are complete managed virtual computing environments that can be streamed or demand-paged over the network. These LivePCs can be shared with others on the MokaFive web site or put on a portable drive for use on different computers.
â
moka5 LivePC Engine makes use of [[VMware Player]] as a virtualization platform, but includes additional features such as automatic updates of virtual machines, streaming and caching of virtual machine images, integrated backup, hardware-accelerated 3D graphics support, and zero install when running from a [[USB drive]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moka5.com/node/836|title=moka5 and VMware Differences}}</ref>
+
MokaFive LivePC Engine makes use of [[VMware Player]] as a virtualization platform, but includes additional features such as automatic updates of virtual machines, streaming and caching of virtual machine images, integrated backup, hardware-accelerated 3D graphics support, and zero install when running from a [[USB drive]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moka5.com/node/836|title=moka5 and VMware Differences}}</ref>
== MokaFive Beginnings ==
== MokaFive Beginnings ==
â
moka5 was founded in July 2005 by [[Stanford]] Professor [[Monica Lam]] with her students Ramesh Chandra, Constantine Sapuntzakis, and John Whaley under the name [[SkyBlue Technologies]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/the_thread/dealflow/archives/2006/05/from_the_khosla.html|title=From the Khosla Portfolio: SkyBlue Technologies|date=[[May 4]], [[2006]]|publisher=BusinessWeek}}</ref> They received their first round of funding from [[Vinod Khosla]] at [[Khosla Ventures]] ($1 million followed by $2.26 million).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/virtualization/archives/2006/05/moka5_to_delive.html|title=moka5 to Deliver PC Virtualization Innovation|date=[[May 16]], [[2006]]|publisher=infoworld.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.siliconbeat.com/entries/2006/05/17/khosla_enters_virtualization_space_invests_in_moka5.html|title=Khosla enters virtualization space; invests in Moka5|date=[[May 17]], [[2006]]|publisher=San Jose Mercury News}}</ref>
+
MokaFive was founded in July 2005 by [[Stanford]] Professor [[Monica Lam]] with her students Ramesh Chandra, Constantine Sapuntzakis, and John Whaley under the name [[SkyBlue Technologies]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/the_thread/dealflow/archives/2006/05/from_the_khosla.html|title=From the Khosla Portfolio: SkyBlue Technologies|date=[[May 4]], [[2006]]|publisher=BusinessWeek}}</ref> They received their first round of funding from [[Vinod Khosla]] at [[Khosla Ventures]] ($1 million followed by $2.26 million).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/virtualization/archives/2006/05/moka5_to_delive.html|title=moka5 to Deliver PC Virtualization Innovation|date=[[May 16]], [[2006]]|publisher=infoworld.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.siliconbeat.com/entries/2006/05/17/khosla_enters_virtualization_space_invests_in_moka5.html|title=Khosla enters virtualization space; invests in Moka5|date=[[May 17]], [[2006]]|publisher=San Jose Mercury News}}</ref>
=== The Stanford Collective Project ===
=== The Stanford Collective Project ===
â
moka5 had its beginnings as a four-year [[National Science Foundation|NSF]]-funded research project at Stanford University called "The Collective: A Virtual Appliance Computing Infrastructure".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moka5.com/products/thin.html|title=Comparison with Thin Client and Hosted Virtual Desktops|publisher=moka5}}</ref> The Collective project was started by the Stanford SUIF group, headed by Prof. Monica Lam, Prof. [[Mendel Rosenblum]], and Prof. [[Dan Boneh]]. The objective was "to develop a new computing system architecture that is secure, reliable, easy to administer, and provides ubiquitous access to users' computing environments."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://suif.stanford.edu/collective/|title=The Collective, A Virtual Appliance Computing Infrastructure|publisher=Stanford SUIF Group}}</ref>
+
MokaFive had its beginnings as a four-year [[National Science Foundation|NSF]]-funded research project at Stanford University called "The Collective: A Virtual Appliance Computing Infrastructure".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moka5.com/products/thin.html|title=Comparison with Thin Client and Hosted Virtual Desktops|publisher=moka5}}</ref> The Collective project was started by the Stanford SUIF group, headed by Prof. Monica Lam, Prof. [[Mendel Rosenblum]], and Prof. [[Dan Boneh]]. The objective was "to develop a new computing system architecture that is secure, reliable, easy to administer, and provides ubiquitous access to users' computing environments."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://suif.stanford.edu/collective/|title=The Collective, A Virtual Appliance Computing Infrastructure|publisher=Stanford SUIF Group}}</ref>
The Collective project began in 1999 with the exploration of a stateless thin-client architecture, a la [[Sun Ray]], where computation would occur on a centralized server.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://suif.stanford.edu/papers/schmidt99.pdf&bJumpTo=True|date=[[December]], [[1999]]|volume=34|issue=5|pages=32-47|title=The Interactive Performance of SLIM: A Stateless, Thin-Client Architecture|first=Brian A.|last=Schmidt|coauthors=M. S. Lam, J. D. Northcutt|journal=Operating Systems Review}}</ref> A thin-client architecture had the advantage of centralized management and allowing a user's data to live in the network, but it had some serious flaws: namely, it was not possible to work while disconnected (e.g. on a disconnected laptop or an unreliable network connection), it required a substantial server infrastructure, and it required a high-bandwidth low-latency network, which was not always possible with distant remote offices.
The Collective project began in 1999 with the exploration of a stateless thin-client architecture, a la [[Sun Ray]], where computation would occur on a centralized server.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://suif.stanford.edu/papers/schmidt99.pdf&bJumpTo=True|date=[[December]], [[1999]]|volume=34|issue=5|pages=32-47|title=The Interactive Performance of SLIM: A Stateless, Thin-Client Architecture|first=Brian A.|last=Schmidt|coauthors=M. S. Lam, J. D. Northcutt|journal=Operating Systems Review}}</ref> A thin-client architecture had the advantage of centralized management and allowing a user's data to live in the network, but it had some serious flaws: namely, it was not possible to work while disconnected (e.g. on a disconnected laptop or an unreliable network connection), it required a substantial server infrastructure, and it required a high-bandwidth low-latency network, which was not always possible with distant remote offices.

As of roughly 19:12 pm (GMT) on the 5th April 2008 the Moka 5 website changed dramatically.The new website is http://www.mokafive.com
â
== moka5 Products ==

== MokaFive Products ==
As of 5th April there are now two Moka Five products:
As of 5th April there are now two Moka Five products:

* Moka Five Express Solution
Line 38: Line 38:
=== LivePC Engine for Windows ===
=== LivePC Engine for Windows ===
â
+
MokaFive LivePC Engine is a Windows application that allows you to run [[LivePC]]s. You have the option to install it on a hard drive or a removable device like a USB stick or an [[iPod]].
â
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:moka5WindowsUI.png|right|thumb|moka5 LivePC Engine for Windows]] -->
  â   â
moka5 LivePC Engine is a Windows application that allows you to run [[LivePC]]s. You have the option to install it on a hard drive or a removable device like a USB stick or an [[iPod]].
 
LivePCs are streamed over the network and cached locally, so you can continue using the LivePC through network disconnections.
LivePCs are streamed over the network and cached locally, so you can continue using the LivePC through network disconnections.
==== Differences between LivePC Engine and VMplayer ====
==== Differences between LivePC Engine and VMplayer ====
â
moka5 LivePC Engine uses the free [[VMware Player]] as its virtualization platform. It adds a few additional features to the standard VMware Player:
+
MokaFive LivePC Engine uses the free [[VMware Player]] as its virtualization platform. It adds a few additional features to the standard VMware Player:
â
* Seamless updates of virtual machines. In moka5 LivePC Engine, users are subscribed to a LivePC so they automatically receive all updates. Updates are sent through an RSS feed that the LivePC subscribes to.
+
* Seamless updates of virtual machines. In MokaFive LivePC Engine, users are subscribed to a LivePC so they automatically receive all updates. Updates are sent through an RSS feed that the LivePC subscribes to.
â
* Streaming and caching of virtual machine images. moka5 LivePC Engine will stream virtual machine images over the network so you don't need to download the entire image before starting. It will also cache the image locally so you can work disconnected.
+
* Streaming and caching of virtual machine images. MokaFive LivePC Engine will stream virtual machine images over the network so you don't need to download the entire image before starting. It will also cache the image locally so you can work disconnected.
â
* Integrated backup. When using moka5 LivePC Engine on a portable device, it will keep a backup so if you lose your portable device, you won't lose your data.
+
* Integrated backup. When using MokaFive LivePC Engine on a portable device, it will keep a backup so if you lose your portable device, you won't lose your data.
â
* Hardware-accelerated 3D graphics support. moka5 LivePC Engine includes support for DirectX 3D programs. The host's graphics adapter is exposed to the guest operating system, so DirectX applications can run full speed.
+
* Hardware-accelerated 3D graphics support. MokaFive LivePC Engine includes support for DirectX 3D programs. The host's graphics adapter is exposed to the guest operating system, so DirectX applications can run full speed.
â
* Zero install when running from a USB drive. When plugging into a host that does not have moka5 installed, moka5 LivePC Engine will dynamically install itself, and then uninstall itself after unplugging.
+
* Zero install when running from a USB drive. When plugging into a host that does not have MokaFive installed, MokaFive LivePC Engine will dynamically install itself, and then uninstall itself after unplugging.
â
<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:moka5BareMetalUI.png|right|thumb|moka5 LivePC Engine Bare-Metal Edition]] -->
 
=== LivePC Engine Bare-Metal Edition ===
=== LivePC Engine Bare-Metal Edition ===
LivePC Engine Bare-Metal Edition is a stripped-down Linux distribution that boots directly into the LivePC Engine software. The Bare-Metal Edition is useful for more secure installations where lockdown is important, such as in a computer lab.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moka5.com/products/baremetal.html|title=moka5 Engine - Bare Metal Edition|publisher=moka5}}</ref> It uses a web-based interface rather than the transparent windowed interface of the Windows version.
LivePC Engine Bare-Metal Edition is a stripped-down Linux distribution that boots directly into the LivePC Engine software. The Bare-Metal Edition is useful for more secure installations where lockdown is important, such as in a computer lab.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moka5.com/products/baremetal.html|title=moka5 Engine - Bare Metal Edition|publisher=moka5}}</ref> It uses a web-based interface rather than the transparent windowed interface of the Windows version.
â
<!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:moka5Library.png|right|thumb|moka5 LivePC Library]] -->
 
=== LivePC Library ===
=== LivePC Library ===
â
The moka5 web site includes a library of publicly-available LivePCs. These LivePCs are mostly Linux and free-software based and work in both the Windows and the Bare-Metal Edition. Users can post new LivePCs to share in the library, or start from an existing LivePC, make modifications, and republish it as their own.
+
The MokaFive web site includes a library of publicly-available LivePCs. These LivePCs are mostly Linux and free-software based and work in both the Windows and the Bare-Metal Edition. Users can post new LivePCs to share in the library, or start from an existing LivePC, make modifications, and republish it as their own.
â
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:moka5Fearless.png|left|thumb|Fearless Browser logo]] -->
 
==== Fearless Browser ====
==== Fearless Browser ====
â
One popular LivePC is the Fearless Browser LivePC, which is currently the default LivePC you get when installing moka5 LivePC Engine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tech.cybernetnews.com/2007/02/21/cybernotes-livepc-brings-safe-secure-and-anonymous-browsing-to-your-desktop |title=LivePC Brings Safe, Secure, and Anonymous Browsing to your Desktop|date=[[February 21]], [[2007]]|publisher=CyberNotes}}</ref> It includes a locked-down Firefox browser with integrated [[Tor]] and [[OpenVPN]] support for anonymous browsing, preventing eavesdropping and guarding against phishing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myjob-online.de/index.php?auswahl=30&option=com_zeitschriften&seite=1&Itemid=535#a289|title=Mit moka5 sicher surfen|date=[[March]] [[2007]]|publisher=OpenSource Magazin (German)}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pc-magazin.de/praxis/anwendungen/a/Fertigloesungen-fuer-die-Hosentasche|title=FertiglÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r die Hosentasche|date=[[May]] [[2007]]|publisher=PC Magazin (German)}}</ref> The Gentoo Linux-based Fearless Browser is also not susceptible to Windows malware.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everythingusb.com/moka5_livepc.html|title=Moka5's LivePC Platform - VMware with a Portable Twist|date=[[January 12]], [[2007]]|publisher=EverythingUSB}}</ref>
+
One popular LivePC is the Fearless Browser LivePC, which is currently the default LivePC you get when installing MokaFive LivePC Engine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tech.cybernetnews.com/2007/02/21/cybernotes-livepc-brings-safe-secure-and-anonymous-browsing-to-your-desktop |title=LivePC Brings Safe, Secure, and Anonymous Browsing to your Desktop|date=[[February 21]], [[2007]]|publisher=CyberNotes}}</ref> It includes a locked-down Firefox browser with integrated [[Tor]] and [[OpenVPN]] support for anonymous browsing, preventing eavesdropping and guarding against phishing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myjob-online.de/index.php?auswahl=30&option=com_zeitschriften&seite=1&Itemid=535#a289|title=Mit moka5 sicher surfen|date=[[March]] [[2007]]|publisher=OpenSource Magazin (German)}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pc-magazin.de/praxis/anwendungen/a/Fertigloesungen-fuer-die-Hosentasche|title=FertiglÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r die Hosentasche|date=[[May]] [[2007]]|publisher=PC Magazin (German)}}</ref> The Gentoo Linux-based Fearless Browser is also not susceptible to Windows malware.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everythingusb.com/moka5_livepc.html|title=Moka5's LivePC Platform - VMware with a Portable Twist|date=[[January 12]], [[2007]]|publisher=EverythingUSB}}</ref>
== Known Issues ==
== Known Issues ==
â
moka5 inherits many of the [[VMware Player#Known issues|limitations of VMware Player]], including no support for IEEE-1394/FireWire and certain other hardware devices.
+
MokaFive inherits many of the [[VMware Player#Known issues|limitations of VMware Player]], including no support for IEEE-1394/FireWire and certain other hardware devices.
â
Because a LivePC includes the operating system, moka5 requires an operating system license for each LivePC, which can be onerous when the operating system is not free. Including the entire operating system also makes LivePCs larger and more memory hungry than using for example [[application virtualization]].
+
Because a LivePC includes the operating system, MokaFive requires an operating system license for each LivePC, which can be onerous when the operating system is not free. Including the entire operating system also makes LivePCs larger and more memory hungry than using for example [[application virtualization]].
== Competitors ==
== Competitors ==
